bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 20, 1930

div1.p: Carter inquires if the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation can track down a reference involving Michael E. Connor.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 20, 1930
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
a) Russell, Report
b) bibliographic
re aljibes, aegypti
breeding
in
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
January 20, 1930.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
1: I wonder whether in your, or in Mr. van Wesep's, files
there is anything in the way of a definite bibliographic reference to
the free breeding of aegypti in the “aljibes” of Yucatan? This re
Father's statement (Section iii, part i, p. 42-a) that these aljibes
“still hold water and breed aegypti freely.” Aljibes, as you know, are
underground storeage places (See “The Chultunee of Labná” by E. H.
Thompson). Father gives no authority for his statement re the aegypti
breeding, and, as he had not been to Yucatan, Dr. Frost has decided that it would
be well, if possible, to find out whom he, Father, was quoting. Indeed,
this is one of the items I brought back from Baltimore, for further in-
vestigation, on January 2, 1930. I thought M. E. Connor my “best bet”
and have just spent a long, hard and unsuccessful day in going over the
correspondance between him and Father. The only even faintly suggestive
“trail” I struck was an undated carbon copy of some notes Father had made
on a MS sent him by Connor, commenting on the Section of Father's History
of Yellow Fever dealing with Yucatan. No mention of aegypti breeding in
aljibes in Father's notes, and as he had evidently returned Connor's
critical MS., I do not know whether Connor spoke of it or not. It would
seem a natural place in which to look for mention of it (Connor's MS. I mean).

Indeed, I do not know whether Father got his data by word of mouth, letter or in
print. I judge, however, that if you and Mr. van Wesep haven't the data
at hand that Dr. Connor could give us a reference for our bibliography.
Will youplease then (in event we can't get the data at 61 Broadway) (a)
give me Connor's address: (b) forward this inquiry to him?

2: I have collected some very interesting additional material
for Dr. Frost (a) books, which I am holding here until he needs them (b)
(b)
-2-
bibliographic cards, which I have mailed him. Not many of the
latter, but the results of a lot of hard work and much reading.

3: I have not been to the Library of Congress since the very
cold weather began a few days ago, as I don't dare risk another ill-
ness as long as there is anything I can do for the book now or later.
I have, however, so many books from the Library of Congress at my
apartment that I am losing no time on account of having to stay in-
doors.

With best wishes and continued hopes that some fortunate turn
of Fate may soon give Dr. Frost the small amount of extra time he
needs to complete the final editing and the Introduction.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter, Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
